4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? We had one cow.

Butter? Made some.

What was the price of butter? 25¢ per lb.

Did you pack eggs for winter? Yes.

Did you make butter? Yes.

What kind of cheese? Whole milk cheese.

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Very little of any.

How did you get fresh meat? Animals killed in fall for winter meat.

How often did you get fresh meat? Rarely.

How did you preserve meat? Smoked, cured, and salted the pork.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? Not in early years.

If so what year was it organized? Not until 1914.

Did you use game? Yes. What kinds? Quail, prairie chicken, and rabbits.

For how long? Sometimes in summer months and often game in winter.

What part did fish play in the family diet? Sometimes we had cod fish when available.

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Sometimes fresh.

Kinds? Jack fish.

13. SOAP

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? Made and kept.

If you made your own, did you use lye? Yes.

What kinds of laundry soap did the grocer handle? Soap and lye.

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Coal and wood.

Where did you get your fuel? From the mountain.

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible. Coal and recently oil.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates) J. P. Owen stove 1897.

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates) No.

By whom was your first cook stove made? Do not remember.

What year was it purchased? 1897. Price? $12.00.

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade) Iron, enamel.

For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other) China.

When did you first see enamel ware? Before 1897.

Aluminum? 1900.

14. Fuel. What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Wood. Where did you get your fuel? From the woods near our home.

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible. Coal and recently oil.

15. Methods of cooking and types of utensils. For cooking, did you use an outdoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? Yes. What year was it purchased? 1897. Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates) 1897.

By whom was your first cook stove made? Mr. A. Brown. What year was it purchased? 1897. What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homestead) Iron. For preparing food? (Chains, earthenware, wooden bowls, other) Chains. When did you first use animal power? Before 1877. All animals? 1900.
16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

Boxes (wooden) and paper bags.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner and supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Breakfast:
- Shortcake, rolled oats or crushed wheat porridge
- Homemade bread, eggs & jam

Dinner:
- Homemade soup
- Potatoes, meat & vegetables
- Winter milk puddings or pie

Supper:
- Meat or eggs
- Fried potatoes & vegetables
- Fruit & bread & butter

20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

Meals were prepared very good and plain, and same pattern is followed.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homegrown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

I still prepare homegrown foods.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandizing, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

Butter and Eggs and Fowl were exchanged at the Discovery store for the purchase of other foods. Some credit allowed at the store until Fowl and dressed pork and packed butter were taken in to clear same.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in the early days during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items purchased above, quality, methods of purchasing, prices, etc., etc. (Use back of sheet if needed).

Butter and eggs and flour were cooked at the boiling stove for the first few years. Then the stove was used until fuel and wood were scarce. Then coal and gas were used.
